awd_titl_txt: PREEVENTS TRACK 2: Integrated Modeling of Hydro-Geomorphic Hazards: Floods, Landslides and Sediment
awd_abstract_narration:
Floods claim many lives, destroy property, and cost billions of dollars annually, motivating the need for improved tools for making predictions. Flooding is typically related to higher precipitation, but there is growing evidence that reduction of a river channel's ability to convey floodwaters as a result of sediment deposition can lead to more frequent floods and increased flood hazards.  Current flood models do not sufficiently resolve sediment dynamics in river networks and related consequences for channel conveyance. The overarching objective of this research is to improve our understanding and ability to forecast flood and landslide risks by targeting key uncertainties of sediment inputs to the system from landslides and debris flows and sediment dynamics in channels.  The investigators will develop process-based models, which will be directly compared with existing operational flood models, so that advancements and innovations at the research level can be moved toward operational models rapidly. Two PhD students and two postdoctoral associates will receive training with faculty and government scientist support in a multi-disciplinary research environment.
 
This project will use Landlab, a recently developed toolkit for modeling earth surface processes, to model upland sediment input and sediment dynamics in channel networks. Landlab will be incorporated into an integrated flood modeling framework that includes distributed hydrology (DHSVM), and fluvial geomorphology and hydrodynamics (Delft3D) models. DHSVM will provide hydrologic forcing to Landlab, which will be used to model sediment flux  that is routed through the watershed by DHSVM and incorporated into  Delft3D for flood prediction. This modeling framework will be applied to Skagit and Puyallup Rivers draining two different sediment-laden stratovolcanos, Glacier Peak and Mount Rainier, in the State of Washington. The Skagit and Puyallup Rivers both have long histories of generating damaging floods linked to sedimentation processes. The modeling framework will be extensively validated with existing observations and remote sensing data to address the following questions: (1) What are the dominant geomorphic processes that lead to sediment supply and channel change in the study systems, and how they can be represented in an integrated flood model? (2) How do geomorphic processes, including landslides, debris flows and channel storage affect flood risk? (3) How will flood risk change in the future given expected changes in geomorphic processes? The integrated modeling framework will evaluate how processes interact over a range of temporal and spatial scales during and between flood events, shaping sediment dynamics, river conveyance, and flood frequency. Improved understanding of flood and landslide risks in these systems will provide valuable information for management decisions to address future flood risks and will be communicated via stakeholder workshops.

por.por_cntn:
The overarching objective of this project was to improve our ability to forecast flood and landslide risks by integrating hydrology, geomorphology, and hydrodynamics models into a modular mountain
to coastline (M2C) modeling framework. This work specifically targets the challenges associated with incorporating sediment sources and fluxes into flood prediction and the multi-hazards associated with the co-occurrence of landsliding with flood events. The modeling framework is developed in flood-prone coastal river systems in the coastal Pacific Northwest (PNW). These study systems experience high sediment loading from hillslope and channel processes, which may reduce channel capacity and increase flood hazards. Furthermore, recent floods and other geological hazards have resulted in a wealth of related observational and remote sensing data in these systems.

This project included data analysis and modeling tasks to investigate the role of sediment on channel change and the development of floods. In data analysis tasks we used existing aerial photography, Lidar-based Digital Elevation Models (DEMs), and long-term USGS gage records to document the sources of sediment from uplands glaciers, hillslopes, and terraces; and investigate channel changes resulting from these sediment sources. The study found that sediment supply from glacial sources are important risk factors for channel change and the formation of floods, as much as precipitation. We identified different regimes of channel change (monotonic, oscillatory, and sudden). Knowing the type of channel change regimes in stream system could benefit flood risk predictions. We found that sediment from retreating glacier can contribute 18-32% (Nooksack River, WA) and terrace erosion contributes 12-24% of the total sediments in coastal rivers of the PNW with glacier peaks. 

Our modeling tasks included the development of models of landslide initiation and debris flow routing; sediment routing in channel networks; and the implementation of the Delft 3D model under different streamflow/climate scenarios in the coastal Pacific Northwest river systems. Results indicate that the inclusion of morphology increases model accuracy on flood extent and volume, especially in areas with active bed elevation changes and channel modifications. These findings highlight the critical role of morphological processes in providing more realistic flood risk assessments and improving the understanding of flood behavior. Our flood modeling studies also underscore how channel adjustments between subsequent high flows could affect flooding, and how hydraulics of overbank flooding can contribute to local morphodynamic adjustment. These findings provide insights for flood risk and floodplain management.  

Intellectual merit: Mapping flood inundation has been traditionally viewed as a problem of hydrology and channel conveyance capacity. Studies on channel morphodynamics during and between high flow events, and how channel changes might affect flood inundation has been limited. In addition, we lack models that can represent how and when sediment sources from terraces and uplands modify channel reaches, travel downstream, and contribute to local flooding. This project developed modeling tools that couple distributed hydrology with sediment generation and transport processes, and identified bottlenecks and future research needs for modeling sediment from source areas to coastal sinks. These tools, including landslide, debris flow, and network sediment transport models are developed using the Landlab earth stuface modeling toolkit, and are available on Landlab Github repository.     

Broader Impacts: This project trained graduate students (2 PhD and 1 MS student), 3 postdoctoral associates, 3 undergrad students. Education and outreach activities included Landlab model trainings to geologists and resource managers in the state of Washington, stakeholder meetings with floodplain managers on flood modeling to understand and mitigate flow overtopping in the coastal PNW; short course and clinics in various professional meetings, as well as teaching modules on watershed dynamics modeling within the CUAHSI Virtual University. The project resulted in 15 peer-review journal papers, which included links to data and model repositories, and contributions to Landlab Github code repository and other individual Github and data repositories.
